resource.name: Educational Attaiment For The Population Ages 18-24 Years- ZIP Code Tabulation Areas 2010-2014
resource.description:
This dataset includes annual estimates of educational attainment for the population ages 18-24. Through its American Community Survey, the U.S. Census Bureau produces 5-year estimates for most geographies in the U.S, and its territories. The educational attainment estimates reports a percentage of the population who have completed increasing levels of education from less than high school completion to a bachelor’s degree or higher. Estimates are for the highest level of education completed.

This dataset is for the Census bureau defined ZIP Code Tabulation Areas (ZCTA). Though roughly formed with the U.S. Postal Service’s ZIP Code areas as a guide, across the nation the ZCTAs do not always conform to the exact boundaries of ZIP Code areas. However, in St. Louis County the boundaries rarely differ.
resource.attribution: U.S. Census Bureau, American Community Survey 5-Year Estimates (Table S1501)

resource.name: Youth Taken Into Police Custody For Criminal Offenses
resource.description:
This dataset includes annual counts of youth ages 10-18 taken into police custody for criminal offenses committed during the annual reporting period. All local law enforcement agencies are required by law to report custody (minors) and arrest (adults) data to the Missouri Department of Public Safety. Data is organized by Part I and Part II offenses and accessible through the department’s Uniform Crime Reporting website. Part I offenses are those that are generally of a violent and more serious nature. Part I crimes include homicide, forcible rape, robbery, aggravated assault, burglary, larceny-theft, motor vehicle theft and arson. Part II crimes generally are non-violent and include offenses such as vandalism, disorderly conduct and missed curfew and loitering. Custody counts may include a single youth being counted for multiple incidents on different occasions.

The per 100,000 youth rate for Youth Taken into Custody for Criminal Offenses is calculated as:

(# Total Youth taken into Custody/Total Youth Population for Ages 10-18) x 100,000.
resource.attribution: Missouri Department of Public Safety Uniform Crime Reporting
